The motivic Rees bundles

Apr 11, 2020

I’m really behind on posting. Trying to motivate myself to do school work, but failing at doing so. In this post, I want to talk about the construction of the motivic -element. (The content of this post is what motivated the previous post.) In this lecture, Mike talked about the Rees bundles and the fact that they have a motivic lift. What are the Rees bundles?

These are rank two (-local) bundles over defined as follows. The first nontrivial odd homotopy of is . Since , we get an element . The Rees bundle is then defined via the composite

Rees showed that these bundles are nontrivial. They also have no Chern class, and are expected to not lift to algebraic bundles. However, the point of Mike’s lecture is that they do lift motivically.

How does this work? Well, (or rather, ) has a nice motivic cell decomposition, and the top cell is . Here, I am using the convention that . Moreover, , so to lift Rees’ bundles to the motivic world, it suffices to define a map which realizes to Rees’ map. (We are omitting some subtleties about this “Juanolou(??) device” that Mike talks about.) So, if we had a map which realizes to , then we get the desired map

What is the map ? Mike constructs this as follows. First, he describes the construction of a map , and we will describe another construction below. Then, this element is -torsion, and so it can be composed with the map which increases the motivic weight by one, and which realizes to the identity. In other words, the desired map is the composite

OK! So we need to define this map . Remember that in the classical world, this element was defined by the composite of with . We’ll define similarly: we will construct a map , and then will be the composite

So, what is ? We will define it differently than Mike. There is a canonical map , and if we work -locally (this is a subtle point motivically, which I will skip over here; I think everything is fine over the complex numbers — hopefully this doesn’t come back to bite me when I work this out in more detail), then this extends to when . In particular, we have a map

Now, as we showed in Proposition 4.25 here, there is a cofiber sequence

One can prove that this is realized by a cofiber sequence

where the first map is the iterated Whitehead product (which can always be defined by the results in my paper with Peter). This implies that there is a map

and so we get a composite

This defines a map ; this is our desired element . You can now run a similar construction as in this post to get a map for every , which is a(n unstable) motivic analogue of the -family. It realizes to the usual -family.
